#Text=Aline Miller
#Text=Aline Fiona Miller is a Professor of Biomolecular Engineering at the University of Manchester .

#Text=She specialises in the characterisation of polymer , biopolymer and peptides , using neutron and x-ray scattering , as well as the development of functionalised nanostructures for regenerative medicine and toxicology testing .
#Text=Early life and education
#Text=Miller studied Chemistry at the University of Strathclyde and graduated in 1997 . [ 2 ]
#Text=She was an undergraduate exchange student at Franklin & Marshall College . [ 2 ]
#Text=Miller joined Durham University as a post graduate student , earning a PhD in 2000 under the supervision of Randal Richards . [ 2 ]
#Text=Miller worked on graft copolymers , which included polynorbornene and poly(ethylene oxide ) , and studied their organisation at air-water interfaces . [ 1 ]

#Text=After completing her doctorate , Miller moved to New Hall College at the University of Cambridge , where she was appointed a Junior Research Fellow and she worked with Athene Donald on cellulose . [ 3 ] [ 4 ] [ 5 ] [ 6 ]
#Text=She was inspired to have a career in research during this fellowship . [ 7 ]
#Text=Research and career
#Text=Miller joined the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology ( UMIST ) in 2002 . [ 8 ]
#Text=She was made a full Professor in 2014 . [ 2 ]
#Text=She continued to investigate the behaviour of molecules at different interfaces , including the air-liquid and liquid-liquid interface .
#Text=Surfactants and polymers can be used to promote or inhibit the crystallisation of small molecules , for example the use of hydroxyl based polymers in the crystallisation of ice cream .
#Text=To mimic how fish use macromolecules to stop their blood freezing , Miller combines antifreeze proteins with ice crystals . [ 8 ]
#Text=In 2004 Miller established the University of Manchester Polymers & Peptides Research Group . [ 3 ]
#Text=Here she works on the characterisation of polymer , biopolymer and peptides , using neutron and x-ray scattering .
#Text=The in-depth characterisation of these materials allows Miller to tailor them for specific applications . [ 8 ]
#Text=Miller also works in biomedical engineering , creating three-dimensional scaffolds through the control of proteins and peptides . [ 8 ] [ 9 ]
#Text=She explores the relationship between mesoscopic structure , material properties and cell response . [ 10 ] [ 11 ]
#Text=She has studied how proteins self-assemble , including what causes them to unfold and form fibril structures . [ 12 ] [ 13 ] [ 14 ]
#Text=The morphology ( roughness , porosity ) and mechanical properties ( such as Young 's modulus and viscosity ) can be controlled through self-assembly . [ 3 ]
#Text=The self-assembling peptides can be conjugated with polymers that are sensitive to pH and temperature .
#Text=Through the synthesis of short peptides with various amino acid sequences the Miller group are studying the self-assembly of Beta sheets . [ 15 ]
#Text=She has developed a biocompatible , biodegradable cardiac patch , created from a thick porous scaffold coated with a material that mimics the extracellular matrix . [ 16 ]
#Text=She also studies the degradation mechanism of these materials . [ 17 ]
#Text=Miller was awarded a small grant from the University of Manchester to develop the synthesis of peptide-based hydrogels . [ 18 ]
#Text=The synthetic peptide hydrogels were so successful that she set up the spin-out company PeptiGelDesign , a group which worked to commercialise hydrogel technologies . [ 19 ]
#Text=Since 2008 PeptiGelDesig n have raised over £6 million in funding . [ 19 ]
#Text=Recognising the reach and potential of PeptiGelDesign , the company relaunched as Manchester BIOGEL in 2018 , continuing to offer peptide-based hydrogels amongst other biomaterials . [ 20 ]
#Text=The hydrogels can be used to improve the quality of drug toxicity testing , DNA sensing and regenerative medicine . [ 20 ] [ 21 ]
#Text=Awards and honours
#Text=Her awards and honours include ;
#Text=1995 University of Strathclyde William Marr Dux Award
#Text=1996 University of Strathclyde Dean 's Honours Award [ 22 ]
#Text=1996
#Text=University of Strathclyde Hackman Scholarship Research Award [ 22 ]
#Text=1997 Sir George Beilby Memorial Medal [ 22 ]
#Text=1999 Imperial Chemical Industries -Dupont Prize [ 22 ]
#Text=2001 New Hall Junior Research Fellowship [ 23 ] [ 22 ]
#Text=2004 Exxon Mobil Teaching Fellowship [ 24 ]
#Text=2008 Institute of Physics
#Text=Polymer Physics Group and American Physical Society Division of Polymer Physics Young Researchers Award [ 25 ]
#Text=2008
#Text=Royal Society of Chemistry
#Text=Macro Group UK Young Researchers Medal [ 26 ]
#Text=2014 Philip Leverhulme Prize for Engineering [ 27 ]
#Text=2014 Finalist for the WISE Campaign Research Award [ 28 ]
#Text=Personal life
#Text=Miller is married to Alberto Saiani , a materials scientist at the University of Manchester .
#Text=They have three children . [ 23 ]
